channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Survivors of the Deadly Hong Kong Fire Are in Limbo
item.description: Hong Kong, with some of the world’s highest housing costs and inequality, must now figure out how to help thousands of residents who lost friends, family and homes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Theodora Yu and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Wang Fuk Court, a residential estate in the Tai Po district of Hong Kong, after a blaze damaged the complex late last month.

item.title: China’s Mad at Japan, and Pop Stars Are Paying for It
item.description: Beijing is curbing Japanese movies, music and art as it seeks to punish Tokyo for its support of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Zelensky’s Government Sabotaged Oversight, Allowing Corruption in Ukraine to Fester
item.description: Ukrainian leaders blame independent advisers for failing to prevent graft. A Times investigation found that President Volodymyr Zelensky’s own administration removed guardrails.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Kim Barker
item.category: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, center right, at the nuclear power plant in the Khmelnytskyi region of western Ukraine in February.

item.title: The ‘Cocaine Superhighway’ Fueled by the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl
item.description: As Washington made combating fentanyl a priority, cocaine trafficking has surged. Nowhere have the ripples been felt like in Ecuador, where criminal groups have run rampant.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, José María León Cabrera and Daniele Volpe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a car bombing in Guayaquil, Ecuador. Car bombs have become common, killing and terrorizing civilians, and gangs frequently clash with the military and the police.

item.title: Gianni Infantino Awards Trump a FIFA Peace Prize and Announces World Cup Draw
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, has been ingratiating himself with the president to help ensure a successful 2026 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, holding a replica of the men’s World Cup, with Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, in the Oval Office in August. Mr. Trump later asked to keep the trophy.

item.title: U.S. Warns of Europe’s ‘Civilizational Erasure’ Through Immigration
item.description: America’s goal should be “to help Europe correct its current trajectory,” the administration said in its new National Security Strategy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Jeanna Smialek and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Trump has made no secret of his disdain for the political leadership in Europe.

item.title: Putin Basks in Praise From Modi on India Visit
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi lauded President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, underlining the close personal relationship between the leaders and their countries’ longtime friendship.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in New Delhi on Friday. They pledged deeper cooperation in defense, trade and energy.

item.title: Yemen’s Civil War Could Escalate Again. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: An armed group backed by the United Arab Emirates has pushed into the oil-rich province of Hadramout, a move that could reignite conflict in Yemen after years of a stalemate.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Forces loyal to the Southern Transitional Council during clashes with pro-government forces in Abyan Province, Yemen, in 2020.

item.title: On Pope Leo’s Visit to Lebanon and Turkey, A.I. Was a Frequent Concern
item.description: On his first trip as pontiff, Leo XIV predictably called for peace and unity. But he also addressed technology’s promise and pitfalls.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo in Bkerke, Lebanon, on Monday. During his six-day tour, he called out the risks of artificial intelligence and other rapidly advancing technologies.

item.title: Wary of Russia, German Defense Minister Pistorius Is Growing His Army
item.description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s defense minister, is pushing to expand its military in case tensions with Russia escalate. That’s tricky in a country where the Nazi era casts a long shadow.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s defense minister, speaking to lawmakers in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: Trump Wants Maduro to Go. Here’s Who Could Replace Him in Venezuela.
item.description: Several senior Venezuelan officials and opposition politicians would have a claim to power in a transition, but all would face difficulties.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela holding a sword during a speech last month. Should he end up losing power, his potential replacement would be largely determined by the manner of his departure.

item.title: Ruined Rice Fields and Broken Rail Lines: Sri Lanka Counts Cost of Cyclone
item.description: Officials estimate the damage runs into billions of dollars, a headache for the island nation just recovering from an economic crash.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Pamodi Waravita and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Locals wading through floodwater from Cyclone Ditwah, at Mannar in northern Sri Lanka, on Thursday.

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Leader, Once for Independence, Turns Toward China
item.description: She says Taiwan must embrace its Chinese heritage to avoid war. Her critics say she wants to steer the island into Beijing’s orbit.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: The Nationalist Party leader Cheng Li-wun in her office in Taipei, Taiwan, in November.

item.title: How Israel’s Settlement Surge in the West Bank Is Displacing Palestinians
item.description: The Israeli government authorized 22 settlements in May, the largest expansion in decades, and Palestinian families are now being forced from their homes.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer, Fatima AbdulKarim and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: “All my memories are in that home. They are not only stealing our land but also trying to cut the roots that connect us to it,” Muhammad Abdulrahman said.

item.title: The Diplomat Who Was Accused of Sexual Abuse but Kept His Job
item.description: President William Ruto faces pressure after a Times investigation showed that his government downplayed or ignored the mistreatment of women working in Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Justin Scheck
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pauline Muthoni Kariuki said her Saudi employer and his friend raped her in 2020. She became pregnant and sought help at the embassy. There, she said, a Kenyan diplomat, Robinson Juma Twanga, accused her of seducing men.

item.title: Trump’s Security Strategy Focuses on Profit, Not Spreading Democracy
item.description: President Trump’s new National Security Strategy describes a country that is focused on doing business and reducing migration while avoiding passing judgment on authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House last month. The National Security Strategy his administration released describes a world in which American interests are far narrower than how prior administrations — even in his first term — had portrayed them.

item.title: Man Who Swallowed Stolen Fabergé Egg Passes It Naturally, Police Say
item.description: The man ingested the egg locket at a jewelry store in New Zealand last week, according to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: New Zealand Police, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “No medical intervention was required, and the pendant passed naturally,” the police said in a statement.

item.title: ICE Arrests Harvard Professor Charged for Shooting a Pellet Gun
item.description: Carlos Portugal Gouvea, a visiting law professor from Brazil, said he would leave the country rather than be deported, according to federal officials. He was arrested after firing a pellet gun near a synagogue.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Billy Hickey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The professor, who is from Brazil, had been teaching at Harvard during the fall semester.

item.title: Air Traffic Control Issue Briefly Grounds Flights at Edinburgh Airport
item.description: The airport, Scotland’s busiest, said it had experienced a technical problem with its air traffic control provider. An hour later, flights had resumed.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Edinburgh Airport in Scotland in 2012.

item.title: How the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl Helped Fuel the Cocaine Trade’s Resurgence
item.description: Across Latin America, cocaine trafficking has surged as Washington has prioritized combating fentanyl. Times reporters traveled to Ecuador to see how criminal groups are wreaking havoc.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The police in Spain displaying tons of cocaine last year at the port in Algeciras after it was transported in a container from Ecuador.

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: Trump’s Relationship With the President of FIFA
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, FIFA, has lauded President Trump at almost every opportunity, even starting a FIFA Peace Prize after Mr. Trump didn’t win the Nobel. Luke Broadwater, a White House reporter, describes the bromance.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Karen Hanley and James Surdam

item.title: Trump Trumpets Peace in Africa Amid War on Drug Boats, in Day of Dissonance
item.description: President Trump presided over a Congo-Rwanda peace deal on the same day his administration was being questioned about potential war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: President Trump trumpeted a peace agreement while hosting President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and President Felix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Stellantis Is in Default for Moving Jeep Production to U.S., Canada Says
item.description: The automaker switched production from Ontario in a bid to please President Trump. But the company defaulted on contracts covering hundreds of millions of dollars in assistance, Canada said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stellantis’s plant in Brampton, Canada. The European-based automaker also produces vehicles under the Chrysler, Dodge and Ram brands in North America.

item.title: When Kids Adopt New Technologies, Hype Can Turn to Backlash
item.description: The arc of mobile phones and social media may foretell the future of artificial intelligence in schools.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: Dominik Duka, Czech Cardinal Jailed Under Communism, Dies at 82
item.description: While in prison in 1981, he befriended the dissident and future Czech president Vaclav Havel. Later, he became a conservative voice in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Dominik Duka in 2010, when he became the archbishop of Prague. Cardinal Duka spent much of his early life under one of the most anti-religious governments in Communist Europe.

item.title: U.N. Warns of ‘Another Wave of Atrocities’ in Sudan’s Civil War
item.description: Paramilitary groups have intensified an offensive on a crucial region bordering Darfur, prompting fears of another massacre.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Displaced people from El Fasher, in Darfur, lined up for aid at a camp in northern Sudan last month.

item.title: After Years of Debate, Vatican Says No to Women Deacons, at Least for Now
item.description: But a papal commission examining the question said further study was required, and advised that women should be given other leadership roles in the Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV in Beirut in November. Some campaigners had hoped that the Vatican, under Leo’s leadership, might allow for the inclusion of women in the lowest rungs of the church ministerial hierarchy.

item.title: Aid Workers Stand Trial for Helping to Smuggle People Into Greece
item.description: The activists provided support to people who sought sanctuary in Greece during Europe’s migration crisis.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: The campaigner Sara Mardini before the start of the trial of 24 aid workers involved in refugee rescues, at Lesbos, Greece, on Thursday.

item.title: Groups Express Anixety as Trump Threatens to Derail U.S.-Mexico-Canada Trade Pact
item.description: Hearings that began Wednesday in Washington reflected anxiety over the future of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact and whether the president could end up scrapping it.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Though President Trump negotiated and signed the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, he said this year that he wanted to make it a “much better deal.”

item.title: Yasser Abu Shabab, Militant Leader Backed by Israel, Is Killed in Gaza, Official Says
item.description: Yasser Abu Shabab, a Bedouin man in his 30s, was at the center of an Israeli project in Gaza to build up anti-Hamas militias.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: Destruction in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, where Yasser Abu Shabab was reported killed on Thursday.

item.title: His Group Made World-Class Measurements of Atomic Elements
item.description: Yuri Ralchenko led one of the oldest teams at the National Institute for Standards and Technology. The fate of some experiments hangs in the air.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.category: National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times

item.title: Amid Russian Sabotage, U.K. Points Finger at Putin Over Novichok Death
item.description: A British woman died from exposure to a nerve agent because of a botched assassination plot that the Russian leader must have authorized, an official report found.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A police cordon around the residential area where Dawn Sturgess was exposed to the Novichok nerve agent in Salisbury, England, in 2018.

item.title: Deadly Attacks in Gaza Test Cease-Fire as Body of Another Captive Is Returned
item.description: Israel launched a military strike after it said Hamas militants attacked its soldiers, the latest clashes in the two months since a truce was signed.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli strike on an encampment in Khan Younis, Gaza. A Palestinian health official said the attack killed at least six people and injured many more.

item.title: Cambodia Shuts Down Group That Laundered Billions in Scam Profits
item.description: A New York Times investigation in March found that Huione’s group of companies were at the heart of a global money laundering network for fraudsters, scammers and hackers.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Huione Pay headquarters in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in March.

item.title: Spain Sees Itself as a Beacon for Immigrants. So Do Many Latin Americans.
item.description: The government presents its migrant policy as a welcoming alternative to U.S. crackdowns. But activists say those arriving on boats from Africa are excluded from that embrace.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Michael Robinson Chávez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luz Fanny Arce Campiño in the restaurant she works in, in Paiporta, Spain, in October.

item.title: Snail Theft Hits France Before Holiday Rush
item.description: Shop owners say the thieves who took 990 pounds of snails must have been escargot cognoscenti.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A snail farm in Souligné-sous-Ballon, in western France.

item.title: Macron Urges Xi to Help End War in Ukraine
item.description: As President Emmanuel Macron of France visited China, its leader, Xi Jinping, said his country would play a constructive role in ending the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in Beijing on Thursday. Mr. Macron was welcomed with a red carpet and honor guard.

item.title: Hamas Returns Body of Last Thai Hostage in Gaza
item.description: The militant group took more than 250 hostages from Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, including 31 from Thailand. The remains of all but one other hostage, an Israeli, have been recovered.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Placards of hostage, Sudthisak Rinthalak, during a rally calling for the immediate return of the remains of all hostages held in Gaza, at Hostages Square in Tel Aviv in November.

item.title: What to Know About Putin’s Visit to India as Oil Trade Dries Up
item.description: The Trump administration, which crippled Russia’s oil sales to India with sanctions, will be watching Mr. Putin’s talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Grigory Sysoyev/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: In this photo released by Russian state media, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi greets President Vladimir V. Putin in New Delhi, where he arrived on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Faces Choices on Russia-Ukraine Talks as Peace Deal Deadline Passes
item.description: The president wanted Moscow and Kyiv to come to terms by Thanksgiving. Negotiations are now stalled, leaving the White House to decide if an agreement is possible anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: “It does take two to tango,” President Trump said after his envoys left a meeting in Moscow with no major breakthroughs in their meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: In Yemen, Separatist Forces Backed by UAE March Into Oil-Rich Region
item.description: The separatists were battling to secure the region’s oil fields, residents and the group’s officials said. Their swift advance could be a turning point in Yemen’s decade-long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Forces from Yemen’s separatist Southern Transitional Council being redeployed from the southern province of Abyan in 2020.

item.title: China, Japan and a New Narrative About World War II
item.description: Arguments about history are proliferating as the postwar order led by the United States crumbles.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: A Chinese veteran with his military medals in September.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Threat of Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has warned that the United States could soon expand its attacks from boats near the coast to targets inside Venezuela, but he has also spoken by phone to its leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro in Caracas in November. According to multiple people close to the Venezuelan government, Mr. Maduro believes he can remain in control and ride out the gravest threat to his 12-year rule.

item.title: Ludwig Minelli, Founder of Swiss Assisted-Suicide Group, Dies at 92
item.description: Dignitas has helped more than 3,000 people take their own lives, an act that Mr. Minelli maintained was a fundamental exercise of free will.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Yegor Ligachev, Gorbachev’s No. 2 Who Turned Foe, Is Dead at 100
item.description: As the Kremlin’s hard-line Communist ideologist, he initially embraced his boss’s modernizing reforms before turning against them as threats to the Soviet order.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Yegor K. Ligachev. Kremlin watchers came to regard him as an enigma, symbolic of Russia itself, teetering between a past of untold suffering and a future of unknown perils.

item.title: Stakes High, Europe Races to Save Its Financing Plan for Ukraine
item.description: The European Union has a proposal for how to turn Russian frozen assets into a giant loan for Ukraine. If it fails, it could further weaken Europe’s global image.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Members of the 31st Separate Mechanized Brigade, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine last year.

item.title: Two U.K. Women’s Groups Ban Transgender Girls and Women
item.description: The Girlguiding organization and the Women’s Institute both said a court ruling from earlier this year had forced their hands.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Protesters in London rallied for trans rights in April after the Supreme Court ruled that only biological women are recognized under Britain’s Equality Act.

item.title: Tunisia Arrests Opposition Figure in Widening Crackdown
item.description: The sentencing of Ayachi Hammami, a prominent human rights lawyer, was the latest sign of Tunisia’s backsliding into authoritarianism, say rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Aida Alami
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Ayachi Hammami is a leading opposition figure in Tunisia.

item.title: On Trump’s Insults, Somalia’s Prime Minister Says ‘It’s Better Not to Respond’
item.description: President Trump referred to Somali immigrants as “garbage” during a White House meeting on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Hussein Mohamed
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, last year. Some Somalis were frustrated by what they saw as a pattern of disrespect toward Africa from President Trump.

item.title: With Tensions Rising, Israel and Lebanon Expand Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Diplomats from both countries joined a military-led committee overseeing a year-old truce as fears mounted of a renewed Israeli offensive against Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Supporters of Hezbollah gathered in September at a crater in the Dahiya neighborhood on the outskirts of Beirut. The hole was left by an Israeli strike in 2024 that killed the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah.

item.title: Israel Says a Gaza Border Will Reopen, but Only for Palestinians to Leave
item.description: Israel had agreed to open the Rafah crossing as part of the October cease-fire deal with Hamas but kept it closed. Egypt denied that the border would reopen soon.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah crossing at the border between southern Gaza and Egypt in 2023. Israel has said it will reopen “in the coming days,” but Egypt denies this.

item.title: Weak Spots Are Few for Russia in Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Economic and military pressures could force Russia’s hand. Its economy is strained but not enough to do that, analysts say. And President Vladimir V. Putin says Russia is winning the war.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with the U.S. special envoy, Steve Witkoff, and Jared Kushner, at the Kremlin, on Tuesday.

item.title: Macy’s Raises Sales Forecast Again as Shoppers Prove Resilient
item.description: Macy’s raised its sales forecast for the year after strong results at its upscale chain, highlighting how higher-income consumers continue to spend relatively freely.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers on Black Friday in New York City.

item.title: Storm Floodwaters in Indonesia Turned Logs Into Floating Projectiles
item.description: Many logs became forces of destruction in Indonesia last week, in a sign that deforestation compounded the devastation wrought by a cyclone.
item.dc:creator: Hasya Nindita, Rin Hindryati and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: The aftermath of Cyclone Senyar in Batang Toru, North Sumatra, on Tuesday.

item.title: Fabergé Winter Egg Sells for $30 Million, an Auction Record
item.description: Fabergé is believed to have produced 50 of the ornate eggs for Russia’s czars. The Winter Egg, sold on Tuesday, is considered one of the jewelry house’s greatest creations.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: The Fabergé Winter Egg displayed at a media preview by Christie’s in London in November.

item.title: Inside the Ultra-Orthodox Fight Against Israel’s Draft
item.description: For the first time in decades, ultra-Orthodox Jews in Israel are being called to serve in the country’s military. The community is furious, with protesters and military-age men openly defying the draft.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Guy Barak, Monika Cvorak, Jon Hazell and Mark Boyer

item.title: Visiting Turkey and Lebanon, Pope Leo Echoed Francis’s Message, Not His Style
item.description: Traveling through the Mideast, Leo XIV channeled many of his predecessor’s messages. Leo’s deliberate manner differed from Francis.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo in Bkerke, Lebanon, on Monday. During his six-day tour, he called out the risks of artificial intelligence and other rapidly advancing technologies.
